Award.AwardTitle: Towards an Assembly Pathway for the Carboxysome, the Prototype Bacterial Organelle.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The carboxysome is a microcompartment that, in cyanobacteria and chemoautotrophic bacteria, plays an important role as a component of the Carbon Concentrating Mechanisms of these organisms. However, the pathway for assembly of the carboxysome is not well understood, and in order to simplify this problem the assembly of the Halothiobacillus neapolitanus carboxysome will be studied in Escherichia coli. The proposed study will extend our understanding of carboxysome assembly, structure and function, and provide insight into how cyanobacteria and chemoautotrophic bacteria regulate the fixation of carbon dioxide.

Broader Impacts: The uptake of carbon dioxide by bacteria is important for our understanding of the global carbon cycle and the impacts of climate change, and knowledge of the carboxysome is relevant to our ability to engineer organisms to produce biofuels. Training opportunities will be provided for graduate and undergraduate students, including those from groups underrepresented in science. Outreach to underrepresented minority high school and middle school teachers and students will provide opportunities for them to engage with this research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to elucidate the self-assembly pathway of an intracellular structure (the carboxysome) in Halothiobacillus neapolitanus that is vital for the ability of this and other carbon dioxide-utilizing bacteria to grow in air. The carboxysome protein CsoS2 was identified as the crucial carboxysome component without which carboxysomes do not form. Furthermore, carboxysome proteins that interact with this protein were identified. 

Since bacteria that produce this type of carboxysome have a neighboring gene cluster that codes for proteins of potential interest to carboxysome assembly, structure and function, several of these genes/proteins were investigated. A new carboxysome component, the protein CbbQ, was identified. CbbQ and its interaction partner CbbO, were characterized, and the effects of both proteins on carboxysome structure, function and assembly were investigated. In collaboration with another lab, the three-dimensional structure of CbbQ was elucidated.  

Additional proteins were identified and characterized, and their effects on growth of the bacterium in air as an indicator of carboxysome function was assessed. Their interactions with selected known carboxysome proteins were established. Furthermore, the independence of the neighboring gene cluster from the genes that encode the major carboxysome proteins was established. This suggests that the carboxysome components encoded by genes in the neighboring gene cluster may not be regular carboxysome components but may instead be part of the carboxysome or affect its assembly only under certain conditions.

This work lays the foundation for future manipulation of carboxysome assembly for biotechnological applications.

The project has provided professional development opportunities and training for 1 postdoctoral researcher (Hispanic woman), two technical support staff (both women), 1 graduate student (male), 7 undergraduate students (all women; 2 African American), and two high school students (both women, 1 African American).
